In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. For a difficult task of only

From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co.

In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps."

By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. Other well known examples are

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. The other, al-Azhar, did acquire this status in name and essence

Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the antennae of male moths can detect the pheromones of female moths over distances of many kilometers. The yellow paper wasp (Polistes versicolor) is known for its wagging movements as a form of communication within the colony; it can waggle with a frequency of 10.6±2.1 Hz (n=190). These wagging movements can signal the arrival of new material into the nest and aggression between workers can be used to stimulate others to increase foraging expeditions. There is a pronounced tendency for there to be a trade-off between visual acuity and chemical or tactile acuity, such that most insects with well-developed eyes have reduced or simple antennae, and vice versa. There are a variety of different mechanisms by which insects perceive sound, while the patterns are not universal, insects can generally hear sound if they can produce it. Different

Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in Jerusalem. The area of its jurisdiction is the entire State. A ruling of the Supreme Court is binding upon every court, other than the Supreme Court itself. The Israeli supreme court is both an appellate court and the high court of justice. As an appellate court, the Supreme Court considers cases on appeal (both criminal and civil) on judgments and other decisions of the District Courts. It also considers appeals on judicial and quasi-judicial decisions of various kinds, such as matters relating to the legality of Knesset elections and disciplinary rulings of the Bar Association. As the High Court of Justice (Hebrew: Beit Mishpat Gavoha Le'Zedek בית משפט גבוה לצדק; also known by its initials as Bagatz בג"ץ), the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, primarily in matters regarding the legality

An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the same racial stereotypes and social messages are present for all children. In the middle class, where most of our stereotypes come from, children are often raised in middle-class households, where racial stereotypes are ingrained into everyday family life. For example, mothers often say things like, "our black kids need to learn to be more like white kids because it is the norm." As a result, children do grow up with the belief that there are "good" Black people and "bad" Black people, not because they all live in a racialized society, but because most of them are raised in a racialized society.

Most studies of adolescents and their parents' perceptions are based upon white middle-class norms, and they often ignore other racial and ethnic groups. Not to mention that most of these studies are done by non-Blacks.

Compared to other team sports, the National Football League preseason is very structured. Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, plus two Hall of Fame Games that can showcase a player's skills while still being meaningless in the standings. But if a player wants to put on another hat when the actual NFL season starts, as Dwayne Allen did with his Miami Hurricanes in college, he can do so under NFL rules.

However, NFL teams don't have to sign a player based just on his performance on pre-season game days. The league's Collective Bargaining Agreement prohibits teams from signing any UDFA (Uncontracted Free Agents) if they have a minimum 90-man camp roster. So if an NFL team has room for five more players, it actually only needs to try to sign five pre-season performers if they intend on keeping those players around.

In practice, not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match. In addition, disqualification could put more strain on the referee than if their attention could be devoted to rule compliance.  In theory, however, most disqualifications are accompanied by a mandatory five-point deduction for the offending player unless the disqualification results from actions of a different type of conduct and the player is at fault for the referee's decision to disqualify them, i.e. when a wrestler commits a shoot or countout. For example, should a wrestler lose the contest due to a disqualification it would have been the wrestler's responsibility to control their emotions.

From the 1970s onward, Stuart Hall's pioneering work, along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and many others, established an innovative new area of study called cultural studies. Hall himself referred to cultural studies as "the study of the internal 'discourses' of cultural formations or practices: literature, art, theatre, film, sports, education, politics.... As a process, cultural studies focuses attention upon the ways in which such practices can be said to constitute and define their social, as much as their cultural,'selves.'" That is, cultural studies is not simply a study of culture; it also examines the ways that culture (literature, art, the mass media, etc.) constitutes the social world around us. Hall was among the first to recognize that the seemingly spontaneous and unselfconscious mass culture of the masses—whether these be the products of popular music, advertising, newspapers, or television—are all _constructed_. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. For example, humans may have a range of hair colors including blonde, light, brown, and black. Colors are due to various pigments in hair, among these are melanins, the brown pigment found primarily in human and primate hair. However, mammalian hair can also include other colors including colors which appear more like blue, violet, red, silver, gray, white or yellow. The differences in pigments in different pelage, within and between mammals, may be controlled with a mutation, altered transcription, differential expression of genes, and/or an environment.

Conventions 
A coalition typically follows certain important norms:
 The cabinet must have a majority in the Knesset, otherwise it can't officially be called a coalition government.
 Ministers from allied parties form a faction in the Knesset known as the Ministry Faction. Sometimes it is called the Knesset Faction as a whole, however.
 Ministers that have lost their post due to a cabinet resignation do not form a constituency within the Knesset and do not join any faction.

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology, particularly with the stress systems. This is important because emotions are related to memory, pain perception, and behavior, as well as to regulation processes that are known to be important for health outcomes across the life span \[[@B34], [@B40]\].

In fact, emotions are considered to be related to stress and pain because of psychological as well as physiological changes. Emotional arousal triggers activation of an affective stress system that releases neurotransmitters like epinephrine and norepinephrine in a short time span. These norepinephrine and epinephrine are part of the physiological cascade related to emotions \[[@B42]--[@B47]\].

Many studies indicate increased autonomic activation for negative emotions and reduced autonomic activation for positive emotions. The implications are multiple as various research traditions are now[when?] heavily utilizing the lens of identity to examine phenomena.[citation needed] One implication of focusing on identity is that identity provides a basis for organizing and interpreting the world. Another implication of identity as a focus of study is its ability to provide a platform for examining the relationship(s) between identity, society (social interaction), the world (the way(s) in which people interact with each other and with the world), and culture.[35]

In philosophy

The concept of identity emerged in philosophy with ancient Greek thought, before it was studied by modern philosophers. According to philosopher Gilbert Ryle, modern philosophers generally regard the issue of identity as a question of what it is for a thing – a person, a group, a belief, a concept – to remain the same through time, by which they refer to the question of whether a thing can continue to exist (and possibly reappear) while undergoing change.[36]

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond the particular, empirical, and contingent. However, rather than merely attempting to articulate what he takes to be inscribed in the Kantian system, Hegel understands himself to be working out of the system, working out the implications, not merely of a system's claim, or of its truth claims, but also of the assumptions that a system's truth can be found in some particular structure. The truth of Kant is, for Hegel, nothing other than the truth of the self-positing of the Idea of the system itself.

In the Neolithic periods of northern and southern Balkans, farmers were cultivating crops and herding sheep and goats. The oldest written traces of agriculture in Balkans date from 7th–6th centuries BC with a reference to a city of Kedrai (now Kedra, Bulgaria) as a “Greek farm.” The practice of agriculture spread to the areas of South Morava River, Pčinja, and South Strymon River and extended to the Adriatic coastline. Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it is knowable or ascertainable by us; that is, it is an intersubjectively or objectively provable or testable kind of belief. Beliefs are distinguished from knowledge by not satisfying the tests of such tests as could not be avoided by delusion. The kind of knowledge which would exist, if the belief in God were a "delusion", would be what Popper calls "nonscientific knowledge" (1966/1972: 72). Popper's notion of the "nonscientific knowledge" corresponds to the metaphysical view that there are entities or properties which do not fit into the scientific method. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent of Pangaea began to break up. In North America, as in Europe (now separated), the earliest and largest rifting event occurs. The Atlantic Ocean opened around the present day location of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. During this rifting, the supercontinent Pangea began to break up into several smaller continents. The formation of the Tethys ocean closed the Atlantic basin during the Jurassic in the later stages. The breakup of Pangea resulted in two relatively stable landmasses: Laurasia (now northern portions of North America, Europe, and most of Asia), to become a landmass later known as Ur-Eurasia, and Gondwana (now Southern South America, Antarctica, Africa, Madagascar, Australia, India, and Antarctica). The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period, and it takes its name from the Gallaeci, a Celtic people, although Celts were preceded by the autochthonous Urnaut people; the area where this culture developed may correspond to the modern Spanish province of Galicia. Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals.
One of the reasons that it is impossible for mammals to fly is buoyancy, or the distribution of the body's mass to a greater surface area increases a floatation effect. To counteract this buoyancy effect, birds must have the most advanced and refined cardiovascular system. A bird's greatest limitation is that there is no room for more extensive systems of oxygen exchange tissue. This makes it a very difficult challenge to try to increase the oxygen content of a bird's blood, through increasing the blood volume through cardiovascular systems. Therefore, if a way is found to increase the ratio of gas exchange surface area, to the blood volume, this will lead to a much higher rate of oxygen absorption into the blood. Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are influenced by personal, social, educational, and other experiences.

##  **Developmental Goal 2.0**

Identity development happens in a series of steps. These steps are a unique characteristic of the adolescent years and the period of identity development that takes place within them. _Identity_ is a general term for the sense of who we are, including our interests, talents, attitudes and beliefs. Identity development takes place over time in stages. As these stages unfold new or existing information becomes part of the adolescent identity. Over the course of identity development, a young person creates a more comprehensive picture of herself. It becomes possible to understand who the person is, what she does, and what she likes. When the young person is able to understand who she is and where she's going, she has achieved a sense of identity.

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance. Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-worth and self-acceptance that characterize the adolescent ego, egocentrism allows the individual to create an identity that is clearly defined. Such is the identity formed by a child's mother and father or teacher when the child is at a young age; that identity may persist throughout the lifetime, or may be modified to reflect changing circumstances. But for the individual who never breaks out of the bonds of self-identification, egocentrism will remain his identity.

During young adulthood, egocentrism is manifested as a set of behaviors that are more openly self-centered and aggressive. In contemporary society, adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform. While some of these, such as emotional distress (fear of abuse by a sexual partner, or of physical health effects such as HIV or pregnancy) are similar to those faced by adults, others are distinctive to this population and arise from issues common to adolescence, such as school problems or the pressure to do well in exams. The latter risk factor is thought to arise from the need of adolescents to seek sexual relationships to establish their identity as sexual persons and, like any other behaviour pursued during this developmental period, can become dysfunctional if carried to extremes. Finally, the experience of sexual relationships during adolescence may also have implications for health that may persist into adulthood, including adverse effects on mental health.

The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries. There is effectively no ethnic heterogeneity now, but in the past all but ~1% of the population were of a single ethnic group (sub-Saharan African), which was replaced by a colonising group from England when it was founded in the early 1600s. The original Bermudians intermarried with the English colonists for about a century, and there has been virtually free immigration into the island for most of the history.

The body’s capability to react to antigen depends on a person's age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented. If a person’s cell-mediated response to the antigen is impaired at birth, an allergy against that particular antigen usually will not occur; however, a response to the allergen might develop at a later time. Similarly, a maternal factor, for example, might contribute to a person’s allergy against one type of antigen, but not another.



Antigens can be allergenic in more than one way. An antigen can be a protein, a carbohydrate, or a mineral or metallic element. For example, latex, a type of rubber, is one substance that can be both a protein and a carbohydrate.

Molecules that fight infection. Immunoglobulins (Igs) or antibodies are proteins produced by B lymphocytes. They help identify dangerous substances that are foreign to our bodies.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid, a waste product of protein digestion. The function of the avian liver in these birds is not to purify the circulating blood, but rather to store nitrogen for future use and to regulate the body's water chemistry.

Fishes have paired kidneys on one side of the body, each kidney performing a distinct role: one excretes nitrogenous waste and the other filters the water for oxygen.

Mammals are uricotelic for much of their early lives: their kidneys filter the blood and excrete nitrogenous waste, but as they mature, their livers absorb this waste to store nitrogen for future use, and also perform many other duties besides (e.g., detoxification of industrial chemicals and drugs, synthesis of cholesterol, secretion of bile for digestion, regulation of blood pressure).

Each collegium was assigned to a particular territory, or "province": Rome, the Campania and Capua, Picenum and the rest of Samnium, Campania and Paestum, Latium and surrounding cities in the valley of the Tiber, and the valley of the Adriatic. When a priest was chosen for a particular province, he served for a specified time, and was then succeeded by another chosen by the voters from that province to serve in his place.

In Homer's Iliad, the names Danaans (or Danaoi: Δαναοί) and Argives (Argives: Αργείοι) mean "the men of Argeia", Argeia being their tribal confederation.

The first attested use of Danann in English was in the 1520 translation of Machault's chronicle Historye of Ercles, the last use being in 1616. It was from Danann that the English adopted the name Scotland, originally the name of a Gaelic tribe, which has been traced back to the Old Irish Danan.

In Irish, the Gaelic "Danaans" are called Danois ("men of Danu"). In Welsh, this is known as the Deheubarth, and in Old Breton, Dei-an(t).

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the participants begin in the ring and must work their way up the stairs and across the top to the ropes. Once at the ropes, they must return to the top and work their way back down (often referred to as the Bottom to Top or Bottom Rung to Top Rung) before being allowed to proceed to the next rung. Upon returning to the top, they must proceed to go up the staircase to the top once again. This continues until someone gets to the top and wins. Other matches have been devised in which it is possible to win the match without getting all the way to the top and back down again. For example, an opponent may be eliminated or disqualified by being tossed over the top rope or hitting the floor below.

A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, true predators eat the prey and are actually responsible for the victim's demise. The term predatory does not necessarily imply animal behavior. For example, a man who uses another as a source or object can also eat or take their life. Thus an archeologist might describe the practice of looting as predatory, since it steals away another living thing—the victim.

This term may also be applied to humans in certain cases. It is common usage to refer to an aggressive or predatory person, even though no person has ever yet been proved to be a true predator in the same sense as animals. It does not matter one way or the other, however, as long as people can agree on which behavior is worthy of the label.

The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, the Clerk of the Senate summons MPs to the Senate to sign the various commissions granted by Her Majesty, including the commission to form a new federal government in the Commons (although this is an enactment, not an exercise of the royal prerogative, which is performed in the monarch's name by the governor-general). For the purposes of the Royal Assent ceremony, the clerk of the Senate is effectively performing the role of the Speaker in the British House of Commons. The clerk has certain rights at the opening of the new session of Parliament, including the right to put questions to the governor-general, as he would do if the governor-general opened a new session as the monarch's representative.

Canada

In Canada, the British monarch is represented by the Governor General of Canada, who acts on the advice of his council of ministers.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and is the single most significant factor regarding how students feel about themselves and how they think others feel about themselves. In essence, self-esteem is one's perception of his or her value and worth, and that perception will determine their level of self-acceptance and, inevitably, self-esteem. Self-esteem is important for several reasons. It is essential that a student develops his or her own concept of self to use as an ego template for identity formation as the student transitions from one major life role to another. As we discussed in previous chapters, the college or university setting provides the most valuable opportunity for self-exploration in which a student can experiment and play with different aspects of his or her identity by changing their look or lifestyle. Most importantly, in order to effectively transition from one role to another the self must be secure enough to do so

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it became a territory. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism that prevailed during the Vietnam War and the relative ease with which the student body could mobilize political energy. The campus’s unique relationship to the state allows for an understanding of class and institutional structures that are useful for reconnecting the experiences of Yale’s youth with the broader state. Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. In the South-East Asia theatre, Indian troops and equipment were key to the Malayan campaign. Over 8,800 Indians were killed: the Indian Expeditionary Force (IEF) suffered 8,900 casualties (3,300 of them killed), compared with 36,000 casualties for British troops. After the war's conclusion, the Indian military was downsized.

The Second World War brought Britain closer to India, with military planning and joint exercises carried out with Indian leaders. On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged by two waves, the first around 8.30 a.m., the second about an hour later. The first attack lasted about a quarter of an hour but the second wave went on for another 20 minutes. The damage to the town was great; there were around 120 people killed, several hundred more injured and the historic Gorbals area devastated. Clydeside suffered the worst civilian casualties of the war in Great Britain. In this case the cause was thought to be lack of air raid precautions, although it has been suggested that the damage was accidental. No German bombs fell on Glasgow and no German bombers were lost to enemy action this month.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and flexible processes. This makes memory much more difficult to study in an objective manner, since we typically do not observe memory directly. Instead of watching memory happen, we can only investigate its mechanisms by examining the consequences of memory on neural or behavioral processes. Moreover, the neural changes and behavioral changes may not directly correspond to memory, and therefore, our ability to infer the mechanisms of memory from observations of neural or behavioral changes is also limited. To overcome this challenge, we need to learn to read not only the memory, but the neurophysical and neurochemical changes associated with memory. A more precise model should provide the link between the changes observed within the brain and associated behaviors, which can be used to further examine the mechanisms of memory. For these reasons, it would seem logical to incorporate knowledge of neurochemistry with the memory models developed in the past decades

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels (e.g., love, anger, sadness), bodily/physiological manifestations (e.g., heart rate and breathing patterns, facial expressions), behavioural or motoric expressions (e.g., smiling, laughing), situational characteristics (e.g., time and place), and psychological characteristics (e.g., beliefs, desires, goals). These are often discussed in terms of an individual's own experiences of emotions. Many sociologists and other social scientists have conceptualized sociological emotions in some or all of these ways: sociologists' ideas about and explanations of emotions, along with descriptions of feelings in terms of their context, can be found in much of the sociological literature (e.g., Turner and Killian, 2007).

The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) were basically the only choices, the people were divided.

It’s true we live in a very divided nation. But just because Americans have become increasingly polarized doesn’t mean that polarization is a new development.

On the contrary, as I’ll explain, the polarization we see today has deep roots in our country’s history, going all the way back to its founding. Polarization can be traced a least partially to the fact that the U.S. Constitution does not create a political organization (like a political party) for the people to choose which will represent them in Congress, the president and the Supreme Court. Instead, the Constitution creates the system we have today where we select one representative (from our district) at large and also two senators (one for each state). Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who was sailing home from a month's bird-collecting trip to the Amazon. As he said afterwards, it was like receiving a letter from another world. The two men became intimate correspondents, and on 14 November their thoughts on the subject were finally brought together in a joint paper for publication, titled _On the Tendency of Varieties to Depart Indefinitely From the Original Type_. In this they outlined a new theory of evolution, in which Natural Selection arose from the interaction between variation and environmental pressure, instead of being an independent creative force.

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology). At the beginning of the 16thC the universities spread far from their original centres of origin. The universities were divided by national law into three types (arts faculties, faculties of ‘theological and legal’ studies, and faculties of philosophy). In the arts faculty a scholar taught his subject from a set of authoritative texts and through disputations. In the faculty of theology students took philosophy lessons in logic and applied theology, and also took theological disputations. Philosophy students in the three faculty system took ‘practical philosophy’ in rhetoric, ethics, politics and the specialised studies of medicine, mathematics etc. Medicine and surgery courses required many practical sessions for hands-on learning. The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend its governing documents. A board-only organization with a small number of trustees cannot amend its governing documents but could form a subsidiary association or corporation with a membership.

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of heresy—the elders must meet with the accused to take up the issue. The elders must be able to prove that the sins were committed and that the charges are true. While the elders can impose a temporary suspension (called a _suspension of communion_ ), permanent expulsion is the last step. Before a member can be actually dismissed, the elders must present the case to all fellow church members and let each vote (or, as specified by church doctrine, lay their hands upon the head of the sinner). The accused may present witnesses, but must justify the accusations. In the case of an elderly woman, for example, the woman's husband may not be able to personally witness any wrongdoings. Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the onset of menstruation), menopause (the cessation of menstruation), and marriage are three common milestones for women. Men in some cultures must experience certain changes in their bodies before they're considered capable of sexual activity; in others, these changes may occur sooner. In ancient Greece, manhood was marked by the ability to grow facial hair. For many Native American tribes, age twelve and thirteen constituted a distinct period of puberty. Among Asian and Melanesian societies, sexual debut for men comes later in life; the men of some Pacific groups don't achieve full sexual maturity until their late twenties or even later. Following the Ulm Campaign, French forces managed to capture Vienna in November. The fall of Vienna provided the French a huge bounty as they captured 100,000 men of the Imperial Army plus the bulk of the Austrian financial resources. The French army also captured a large amount of enemy battleworthy equipment and supplies that were then transported back to France. The total cost of the campaign from the outset to the fall of Vienna the following November was the capture of over 200,000 men, 1,750 guns, and 4,000 ammunition wagons. The French army sustained 2,000 casualties in the campaign (3,000 during the Ulm campaign), Austrian casualties were unknown, though it is known that the loss of Vienna took a heavy toll on the city's citizens.

The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", they were in fact migrations and invasions were not the normal method of migration in history. The Germanic peoples of the fifth, sixth, and seventh centuries had no tradition of migration, and such movement into former Roman possessions in Western Europe as there was, was confined to the coast of the North Sea, as well as to Britain, the Atlantic coast of the Iberian Peninsula, and even to the eastern extremity of that peninsula at its only foothold in Europe in this period. That being so, one cannot speak of a specific "Germanic invasion" of the West. What there certainly was in the West was a migration of Germanic tribes. Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of the class at the end of 11th grade.

The results have sparked calls for a return to more demanding education.

“This is outrageous,” said teacher Midge Rae. “A good education should not be dumbed down.”

The comprehensive school, an experiment of unparalleled scale and ambition, has long drawn the ire of the German public which voted by a wide margin to scrap the project in 2014. After spending millions on new buildings, it was reported that students were performing badly, falling behind and failing to engage with the school.

Hans-Dieter Münch, a member of parliament for Chancellor Angela Merkel’s party, branded the system “a failure from the very beginning” following reports that pupils of average academic ability found themselves at the bottom of the year 11 German class.

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (primarily Italy, Spain and Portugal) parts developed in much the same way: they saw universities as self-financing through wealthy students coming to study for at least four years. This was a way of funding the universities and building up the student’s family’s wealth and position in the social hierarchy. Only for the noble-class sons of royalty would universities be funded entirely by the student himself, as happened at Padua from the 1340s; elsewhere this tended to be the case for eldest sons. Students from middle-classes or the lower orders would have to work their way through university. It was not until the 16th century that universities were free to everyone with a good enough record. This may seem a retrograde step in the direction of universality, but as it enabled more people to complete university, it was actually a step

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A biological sample containing the suspected agent is added to the medium. The sample is allowed to incubate for a specified length of time under conditions which support growth of the agent. The agent is then identified based on various criteria such as: changes in media color and turbidity, observation of colony morphology, or production of certain metabolic products. Because of its inherent selectivity, culture-based methods are considered to be one of the most important and versatile analytical tools available to the medical and diagnostic community.
In their most common embodiment, microbial cultures require the use of liquid media in which growth of pathogens occurs. The presence of the selected agents in the culture, and the observation of their growth, can be determined by means of a microscope or unaided visual inspection. Typically, a number of agents in the sample are suspected to be present at variable concentrations and relative ratios

While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned, Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture.  It is possible that folk traditions influenced the development of the churchly procession in Florence.  It is also possible that it was the other way around, that the churchly procession derived from the customs of Florentine guilds.  Regardless, there are still remnants of the medieval guild traditions of carnival processions left in the parade that is part of the modern carnival season.  Guilds were organized associations of businessmen and craftsmen who performed specific functions, and which had their own festivals and holidays.  In Florence, specific groups would come together to decorate their costumes and to take part in the parade.  A guild-member could be granted special privilege to wear a costume that was not available to the public.

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much self-regulation. They often have poor emotional control. Adolescents exhibit similar behaviours and also struggle to set and maintain effective limits to their impulses. Such behaviours in adolescents are associated with emotional regulation problems. Furthermore, when parents have their own emotional and behaviour regulation problems, they are likely to set bad examples and lack constructive parenting practices. This leads to adolescent's emotional problems.

There are many external factors which influence adolescent behaviour (see Socialization). An adolescent is often surrounded by people encouraging bad behaviour (such as rebellious friends) and by those who set bad examples (such as unsupervised after-school activities). The influence of peers and the media have also changed. Social media and video games can bring new challenges for adolescent emotional well-being. In response to the early-to-mid-17th century "continental rationalism" John Locke (1632–1704) proposed in his 1690, _Essay Concerning Human Understanding_ that human beings can acquire knowledge firsthand of material things by their senses, and secondly, that we have a faculty of the human mind, intuition, which can also allow us to obtain knowledge about non-material things like God and the soul. This latter form of knowledge is, Locke says, intuitive knowing or knowledge of God, which we acquire by a revelation from God. In this case, the primary source of knowledge, the thing known, is outside of the knower in a personal source of truth.

Homer refers to the "Hellenes" (/ˈhɛliːnz/) as a relatively small tribe settled in Thessaly and mentioned several times in the Iliad, and the people of Troy when they were under the control of the Achaeans. Some scholars believe that Homer used the name Hellenes to refer to a wide variety of Greeks, as is done in modern times; others believe that a single Hellene or Hellenic population is the only population referred to by the name. In the Iliad, the Hellenes form a confederacy as they are described arriving as allied contingents to assist the Greek forces defending Troy, but in later times they are distinguished from the autochthons or autochthones, a group that in the epic are described as the main population, though most scholars see the autochthons as a generic term for Greek-speaking native inhabitants and the Hellenes as a tribal division.

Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert control over territory which, during the Hundred Years' War, had belonged to the English crown. In 1438, a parliament was created and the king agreed to hold off from attacking the English on his wife's side of the Channel. Further, in 1445, the French began to attack the English at sea and their first attempt at a naval war resulted in disaster. A second attempt a year later resulted in the capture of Harfleur and King Henry VI of England agreed to become Henry V of France. During the Wars of the Roses (1455-1485), English nobles fighting on the Lancastrian side formed the House of York and claimed the English crown for five years. However, the battle was one-sided almost from the beginning. The reasons for this are the subject of continuing study by military strategists and academics. Some historians say it was due to the overwhelming numbers and firepower of the attacking North Vietnamese forces, which is certainly one possibility. Even so, this type of conflict had taken place thousands of times prior to the Tet Offensive and the outcome had never been in doubt. Some have said it is because the South Vietnamese were unprepared and unable to offer any kind of organized resistance, while others believe a contributing factor could have been the fact that the North Vietnamese had tapped into the American command and control structure, resulting in an overkill of conventional weapons. Many historians have theorized that a possible factor in the outcome was that the Tet Offensive was launched only after the United States completed the withdrawal of troops from Vietnam in March.

The European concept of "race", along with many of the ideas now associated with the term, arose at the time of the scientific revolution, which introduced the idea of categorizing the various peoples of the then known world into groups, in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, many scholars sought means of categorizing the various European ethnic groups. During the middle of the century, Blumenbach became dissatisfied with existing ethnographic terms, he devised a new one: Teutons. The concept of Teutonic Race took its first steps from various scholars who had been conducting anthropometric measurements of Europeans for years, the results of these measurements were published in print in 1869 by Theodor Waitz. The publication of his seminal anthropological work titled Anthropological Treatises, written, compiled and edited by Rudolf Virchow, the paper is today considered as one of the most important landmark studies in the field ethnology. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), for military and political influence that ended in the victory of the former in 1989. The Space Race is commonly considered as a part of the Cold War, an era of political and military tensions between 1951 and 1991. The race was an important element of the American space program, which carried many spin-offs into other fields of technology, including computers, weather forecasts, medicine, and communications. The Space Race involved technological development in both superpowers to achieve technological superiority in space through the creation of orbital satellites and intercontinental ballistic missiles, with each side aiming to demonstrate that its system could deliver weapons of mass destruction anywhere on Earth.

The technological and military lead provided by the Soviet space program during this period is seen by historians as critical, as it contributed to the Soviet leadership's confidence in pursuing the Cold War to a favorable conclusion despite American numerical supremacy

Established bands made something of a comeback in the mid-1980s. After an 8-year separation, Deep Purple returned with the classic Machinehead album and a tour that was captured on 1988's Live at the Palais. Led Zeppelin finally returned with two live releases capturing the essence of the band's live sound—the In Through the Out Door double live set and Coda. For the latter, the band again employed their longtime engineer Andy Johns, who had worked on many of their albums since 1970. The band put out their first four-track demo tapes since 1975, which consisted of basic tracks with vocals and drums in the left and right channels.

In late 1987, Led Zeppelin guitarist Jimmy Page left the band. Page's departure did not slow the band down—in fact, it brought the band to full stride. The band returned to the studio in spring 1988 and produced another four-track demo to submit for consideration for the new album.

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 mm (24-47 in). In humid climate zones, cotton cultivation is not recommended. Rainfall of up to 400 mm (16 in) is needed to encourage growth, but too much rain will lead to flooding of the soil around the growing plants. Cotton requires more and greater water than most other field crops, and even when the need exists, the ability of the plants to obtain it may be too limited. Irrigation may be necessary depending on the type and extent of soil.  Irrigation water may cause excessive salinity through leaching or transpiration.

Mary's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium, but her position was unique in relation to it. This was because Byzantine theologians of Mary's time were familiar with a range of ideas about Christ's total sinlessness, which made it possible for them to hold that the sinlessness of the Virgin was more or less commensurate with that, or even greater, than Christ's. In the fifth and sixth centuries, the concept that Christ's sinlessness could be diminished in Mary's case, so that she had a greater share of her Son's holiness, was widespread. This idea was theologically attractive to its adherents because it allowed them to argue that Mary had a unique and important role to play in salvation history. For those who saw God's redemptive plan in terms of a mystical marriage, Mary's role was particularly significant, and she was conceived as having given her consent

In October 2014, the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began. All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office relating to paying police for information about an alleged VIP paedophile ring. The jury in the trial was discharged after deliberating for fewer than three hours. The judge in the case, Mr Justice Fulford then announced himself "not sure" the charges under consideration were not "in respect of a matter of public interest" and refused to continue the case.

On 2 July 2016, the Crown Office decided that the case was not in the public interest to prosecute. The Crown subsequently asked for an investigation into the conduct of Scotland's prosecutors who approved the prosecution of the charges.

Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Controlled) architecture made it difficult to improve the performance and power consumption of low-cost desktop computers for consumers and small businesses. Instead, Apple chose IBM to make the PowerPC chips that ran on early versions of its Macintosh computers. Since the mid-1980s, Apple used Motorola's 68000 family of chips for its Macintosh computers. Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a firm position in their mind stating,'my family is my first love'. You may feel uncomfortable with this level of exclusivity. Yet if someone says, 'I am not having sex with my partner until we are married, except for two periods of six months each', and this can be explained as an exclusive boundary, this will not cause any offence or make the person seem prudish. Their reasons may be explained and understood, and it will not offend or insult other people's sensibilities. If the exclusive boundaries stated by a person seem to cause discomfort to others, then these are likely to be regarded as 'not boundaries', but instead as rigid positions.

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably insectivores (similar to today's shrews), they soon diversified into many different forms, and the insect-eating diet was abandoned by many during the Cretaceous period. This was despite an abundance of insects – the Cretaceous 'Age of Insects' – and the development of an impressive variety of mammals with adaptations for insect predation. These early insect-eating mammals were mostly smallish, nocturnal animals – the first mammals were largely inoffensive and went completely unused by the public at large, except of course to the birds and invertebrates that were eaten instead. In 2012, Abigail Fisher, an undergraduate student at Louisiana State University, and Rachel Multer Michalewicz, a law student at Southern Methodist University, accused Harvard of gender discrimination by offering different admissions standards to men and women. The two sought to test a 2008 Supreme Court decision that struck down one part of a university’s race-conscious admissions process.

The Supreme Court had struck down a University of Texas admissions policy because it had taken race into account in a way that had an unfair impact on Asians, who needed admission to the university to meet the state’s race-blind admissions guidelines. But the court also said that if there was a “sufficiently strong justification,” the state could reintroduce race into the process to address the lingering effects of its past discrimination.


Harvard contended that the justices’ ruling only applied to the University of Texas and that its own admissions program was constitutional because it was race neutral. The court refused to hear the case.

In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. One hundred years after the fall of Constantinople in 1453, Pierre Belon described in his work Observations in 1553 that pissasphalto was served as a luxury in Constantinople. The Greeks mixed white wine with water, salt and vinegar, and poured it over crushed lemons for their guests. Those who liked spicy foods could then add crushed pepper. The resulting concoction was a popular appetizer and also used to marinate lamb.

The name of the dish was in fact derived from the Greek word phaza meaning lemons (sphágê is the Greek word for lemons).

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of wounds included garlic, honey, beer, and vinegar.

In 18th century Europe, a few notable physicians, including Francesco Redi, Giovanni Battista Morgagni, and Giorgio Baglivi observed that wounds of animals that had not been cleaned of foreign materials rapidly became infected, while wounds that had been cleaned remained sterile.  It was not until the late 19th century that the use of antiseptics in wounds became widely practiced, beginning with Lister in 1867 who had observed that wounds cleaned with carbolic acid remained sterile despite contamination with various disease-causing microbes. Antiseptics were also used in the treatment of gangrenous infections of limbs, which can be fatal when they get loose and start to eat away at other tissues, especially the blood.

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped during the match and as such there is no added time for time-wasting. The match ends with a draw if regulation time expires and the score is level. If the score is level at the end of the 90 minutes, the winner will be deemed to be the team that scored the last goal. At international level it is decided by drawing lots. If after 90 minutes, the score at the end of the match is level at the end of all of the periods, a draw is declared.

Each half, or 'period', is taken progressively, except when the referee brings the game to a close, or considers the result to be decided as a result of injury (in such a case, the match is immediately stopped and a free-kick awarded). Allusions to legal issues in To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside of the courtroom, has drawn the attention from legal scholars. Claudia Bokelmann and Mark N. Cohen assert that the novel "exemplifies liberal justice, which, to many, is a justice lacking, or one that does not work well for racial minorities, who are generally deemed undeserving of equal access to the system."

Social issues

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the brain strengthen and new connections are formed. This process has been called “sleep in the brain” . It serves many functions. One significant benefit of this process is to facilitate the translation of experiences into memory. By allowing dreams to process the night before during sleep, the day to come will be better. Dreams have the ability to replay past experiences in what amounts to a form of working memory that allows the brain to learn and retain experiences beyond one’s waking state.
In one sleep experiment, subjects who were allowed to sleep for 10–12 hours performed significantly better on a memory task the night after learning it, than those who just stayed awake for the same amount of time. Sleep facilitates memory consolidation and it also facilitates the creation of new memories from an existing one. Research shows that sleep allows our existing memories to become stronger over time.

As a race-conscious measure towards the development of a qualified workforce the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) established land-grant colleges dedicated to training the next generation of agricultural experts. The feathers may be described in various ways, depending on the type of feature in question. As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these free radicals are known as superoxide and hydroxyl, and the process by which they are "broken down" is known as free radical scavenging.

Oxidative stress occurs if not enough "free radical scavenging" occurs and/or if "free radicals are formed" in greater numbers than can normally be controlled. Oxidative stress can damage DNA (and thus potentially lead to mutations), proteins and lipids. This can lead to cellular death. This process is thought to be linked to many different diseases of the liver. It has also shown to play an important role in the development of atherosclerosis in diabetic patients.

Despite Martin Luther's harsh polemics against his Roman Catholic opponents over issues concerning Mary and the saints, theologians appear to agree that Luther adhered to his church's traditional position on these issues. As far as Luther himself was concerned, it doesn't matter much if those who confess Christ don't believe in the doctrines of the Holy Trinity, grace, predestination and Christ's bodily resurrection for them to be Christians at all. The Christian Gospel can be defined solely in terms of its content, rather than what people believe about that content. And a person is not saved simply by making a positive confession, since their "faith" can be faulty and even nonexistent. For example, the fact that Rome teaches that the blessed Virgin Mary was and always will be a virgin after the birth of Jesus does not affect the Gospel—which is all that Luther and some of his fellow reformers ever believed was necessary for salvation, that a person must confess and believe that Jesus died in the sinner's stead

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by a number of minor states. The most notable of them was the Yue State (越國) from around the 12th century BC.

When the Zhou migrated northwestward in the 11th century BC, the various states they encountered were generally defeated and incorporated into a new larger system of states known as "Lu". By the late 6th century BC this was known as Chu (楚國).

Chu was not originally a single political entity. The name "Chu", however, was adopted as the name of the state in later times. The term's use to refer to the Zhou dynasty has thus obscured any distinction between the early Zhou kingdom and later Chu.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be preyed upon — even by humans — by some species of owl and fox.

Prey are usually larger than their predator. The prey often has more defenses (for example, feathers). It has more potential for escape, because it can move more quickly. It can usually move away, while the predator usually has to wait until its next meal for another chance. The prey can live longer because predators are often faster in their attacks, and can attack multiple prey in any one time, while prey is usually not a predator's only meal.

Predator and prey 

Predation—the killing and eating of a weaker animal by a more powerful one.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. A number of native Germanic kingdoms arose in the region, including the Franks, Burgundians, Saxons (Wends), Gepids, and Lombards. Byzantine control collapsed as the Slavs invaded in the mid-6th century from the east, forcing the Empire into a long decline.

The Lombards defeated the final Ostrogothic resistance in 567, and conquered Italy within twenty years. The Eastern Roman Empire, reduced to the territory of the Balkans and Asia Minor, had little military power to resist, and fell to the new barbarian kingdoms.

The title of "world's oldest airport" is disputed, but College Park Airport in Maryland, US, established in 1909 by Wilbur Wright, is often considered the world's oldest intact continuously operating airport.

On July 15, 2016 it was confirmed that the earliest-known airport, on the island of Rhodes, Greece (now Iraklio) was established approximately 4,584 years before the modern age (AD 782). It was built by civil engineering pioneer Deinocrates.  It was likely built for defensive and logistical purposes by the Minoans in the First Millennium BC (Prehistoric Period).

In 2018, research presented at a conference found airport archaeological remains at Qos in the Upper Egypt and dated to approximately 5,000 years ago.

One of the notable authors of esoteric interpretation prior to the 12th century is Sulami (d. 1021) without whose work the majority of the authors who came after him would have been incomprehensible.  His book, Kitāb sulūm al-ghayb or Sulūmī's Key for Entering the Unseen, is not only a major influence for later Sufi writings and scholars, but remains a cornerstone of esoteric thought in Muslim esotericism. Sulami's work was a vast commentary on a hadith, one of the earliest Sufi commentary-based approaches to Islamic esoterism.

One of the earliest Sufi treatises of Sufi esotericism of the Medieval era was authored by Al-Shaykh Al-Mufid (The Master of Purity) (died 505 AH). He was among the earliest interpreters and a Sufi teacher in Baghdad.

On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders along with the establishment of two states: 1) an Arab State in Palestine, and 2) a Jewish state in Eretz Yisrael. Jews accepted the plan while the Arab leadership rejected it.

The State of Israel was declared on 14 May 1948. However, the invading Arab armies failed to defeat the Israeli armies and by the end of October 1948, the Arab armies had been defeated. The United Nations convened in December 1948 as a result of this Arab defeat and approved a resolution which called for the creation of 2 states, 1 Arab and 1 Jewish.[1]

The Arab League also called for a cease-fire because the Arab armies were defeated. This cease-fire became effective on 26 May 1949. Israel agreed to this cease-fire and Israel accepted the borders set out by the U.N. Partition Plan

The Third (1919–23) and Fourth Aliyahs (1924–29) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to Palestine. This influx of settlers did not always go smoothly. By the middle of the twenties it became clear that the Arab nationalist movement was gaining strength. Many of the Jewish immigrants did not want to buy land from those Palestinian Arabs whose lands they had taken. Arab nationalists regarded Jewish immigration with growing suspicion and hostility.

The violence that broke out in 1936 between the Arabs and Jews was precipitated as much by the Zionists' efforts to buy land from the native owners as by the refusal of Arab landowners to sell. That same year the Peel Commission recommended that Great Britain should impose a quota system for Jewish immigration to Palestine and that an independent Palestine should be established within 10 years. The Zionists, however, did not agree with the commission's report and instead tried to gain the right to make their own immigration law, without reference to Britain.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at the brilliant dawn that lights France, might not be without some desire of following it". But by May 1790, although his view was softened, Burke became outspoken against the Revolution. He opposed the calling of the Estates-General, which had been convened and dissolved three times in one year by Louis XVI. Although the calling of the Estates-General on 5 May 1789 was unconstitutional, the Estates-General consisted of three separate groups whose members were all eligible for election as deputies to the National Assembly. Burke held the view that the calling of the Estates-General was a scheme of subversion against the Old Regime created by Louis XIV at the expense of the nobility and the nation. Burke believed that Louis XVI was weak and could not protect the nation against the growing "rage for reform" in France.

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 5,000 years old and it became known to early Europeans when the Phoenicians, who used it for decorative purposes, were trading with them along the Mediterranean in the sixth century B.C. E. This was followed by the Romans, who were using copper for different purposes, including the first coins (450 B.C.-400A.D.). By around the fourth century A.D., the Arabs were using copper plates as a basis for printing on paper. However, it was during this same period that the smelting of copper developed into a complex, commercial enterprise and as smelting techniques improved, the size and quality of copper plates made available to the process increased exponentially. Copper became the primary metal used by artisans during this period.

Great Britain, as a mainland, is more elevated than Ireland, with central England ranging between about 130-160 metres (427-525 feet), whilst some mid-western counties attain 200 metres (659 feet). Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought, and smell of food; the gastric phase occurs when food is actually swallowed; and the intestinal phase occurs when nutrients pass into the intestinal tract. The entire process of digestion takes between one and five or six hours on average.

The digestive tract is a complex and extremely important part of the body. It is made up of the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, rectum, and anus. Food, liquid, and other liquids are broken down through chemical processes. The digestive system also helps to absorb nutrients from food and move waste from the body. It also helps to protect us from harmful toxins and other foreign particles.
