The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and accidentally) from one geographical area to another. Such range extensions are often facilitated by human activities (e.g. international trade). A species (even a well-known one) can become an exotic species to an unfamiliar habitat. In fact, exotic species already account for more than one-fifth of all species, affecting over 1 million hectares of agricultural land alone and costing the global economy an estimated US\$1.2 trillion each year ([@bibr09]). It should be stressed that, in principle, an exotic species can be native to another region or country (for example, the American gaboon viper, a snake native to Central Africa, is an exotic species to South Africa). In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula and prevent them from joining up with other Austrians to defeat Great Britain’s forces in Egypt. Once again, Napoleon did manage to quickly overwhelm the more modest Austrian forces, but in this case his success was in large part due to the incompetence of his nominal allies, the Italian states, which let him take control of much of central Europe even while he was still in Italy. This angered Italian nationalists, who would fight both the French armies and the Austrians in the months ahead, and who were convinced that Napoleon’s success was due to nothing other than his personal ability to use and manipulate the forces of history. The battle of Campo Tenese (June 18, 1800) was one of the largest battles ever held in Italy, and the loss of it was the beginning of a downward spiral for the Italian people and government

The "Bleacher Bums" is a name given to fans, many of whom spend much of the day heckling, who sit in the lower part of the grandstand behind the last row of seats. Most of them sit in the 100 level, while others will get above that and sit in the 600 level or the press box. They are also known as the "M&M's," a nickname derived from the noise made by the constant chewing of candy.

Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current from the top of the electrified rail. The current then circulated around the tram's running wheels. Trams that operated within enclosed systems used pantograph systems, where a collector shoe and contact spring were suspended from the roof of the tram car and were lowered over the top of the electrified railway. The collector shoe then collected the electric current for the tram's overhead pantograph.

Railways 

Early tram lines were mainly of an interurban tramway type, where a route is operated with a fleet of different trams, or with smaller fleets on different routes. This results in many different types of tramcars. A fleet of trams operated together in a city-centre loop system is also sometimes called a tramway.

In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of the two inventions, the phonograph did not lead directly to the microphone; the latter was not invented until the early twentieth century. However, one man, Emile Berliner, did pioneer the development of practical microphones before Edison, in 1897. In a demonstration for Queen Victoria at the Royal Institution in London, he played Johann Strauss's _Eine Alpensinfonie_ on a hand-tuned glass-bead phonetic instrument.

Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Poland in September 1807. The Poles were defeated at the Battle of Raszków on 27 September. In November, Alexander I began negotiations with Napoleon. The Treaty of Tilsit was signed on 9 July 1807, ending all armed conflicts between Russia and France. Russia returned to the Continental System, withdrew from the League of Armed Neutrality and gave up its alliance with Britain (see Anglo-Russian War (1807–1812)), while France evacuated its troops from the Principalities and gave up Malta and Elba. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and reproduction, development of tissues and the maintenance of homeostasis and function of all the systems present. At the cellular level it is required for all reactions involved in metabolism. At the organism level, all life processes involve some combination of energy transformations.

In philosophy, energy is commonly used as an ontological category for all objects possessing energy, and not limited to systems of physics or chemistry, which were the original domains in which energy is used.

Etymology 

Etymologically the word was introduced to science in 1847 by German physicist Gustav Robert Kirchhoff, who defined as "the capability of doing work," which is a physical quantity that can be "translated to, or changed into"  mechanical work. Kirchhoff used the term to refer to the "capacity to do work on a system."

Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by the figure of Christ, whose Passion was shown with increasing elaboration: Christ carried the cross along his shoulders, supported and propped up by a crowd of attendants, as he was slowly tortured to death. These scenes of agony and martyrdom became the main focus of Carolingian sacred art. At the same time, the figure of the prophet Daniel was used as a model for a new type of patron saint, often called a "royal saint" or "protector saint", whose role was to protect the person depicted from the dangers of misfortune and disaster in this life, and to guide him/her to a prosperous afterlife. The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy and had established a powerful colonial army, the Garde National, which became France's strongest military presence outside its territory. However, the situation in Haiti was fragile, and French rule there was threatened constantly by black forces rebelling against the whites.

In contrast, French rule was widely accepted in Martinique, Guadeloupe and Réunion. In response to these developments, Napoleon ordered his Minister of the Navy to "prepare an expedition to retake Saint-Domingue", the last remaining major French colony.

Following the unveiling of Windows 8, Microsoft faced criticism (particularly from free software supporters) for mandating that devices receiving its optional certification for Windows 8 must include a back door for Windows update, which could not be disabled. Though this back door would allow anyone to reprogram and remotely wipe any Windows 8 device (whether sold or given away for free), only Microsoft could access the data it held. A compromise was reached with the Free Software Foundation and the Open Source Initiative to require Microsoft to provide a "Boot to Recovery Environment" in UEFI firmware that would allow users to boot Windows 8 with a non-default hard drive partition. This was implemented in Windows 8 Pro and would also allow users to disable the Windows 8 back door. Microsoft also decided to provide a version of Windows 8 without any preinstalled software.

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid, by introducing an entirely novel conception of epic poetry, proved the most influential model for the great poets of the High Renaissance and subsequent periods—above all the imitators and followers of Dante. The form that Virgil gave the epic in itself was not much altered from that which the Greeks gave: epic poem was still an account of human history (a world history, that is, rather than the local history of a single city). Virgil's greatest innovation, however, was in giving the epical mode to a new kind of subject matter—that of the individual and his destiny. He showed that, even in antiquity, this subject matter was possible to the epic form, which traditionally focused on public affairs and military exploits. Furthermore, he showed the form that the epical poet might pursue. The theme of the Aene

By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers) in the Deccan plateau. The Marathas were the most powerful Hindu power in India by the late 18th century.

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's launch, which left little time for a new competitor to build up a space program.

The launch occurred at an opportune time for President Dwight Eisenhower, who wanted to prove to the American public that the US was capable of winning the space race and would win it for real this time. He made his famous speech "We Choose to Go to the Moon" right after the launch. The launch also helped spur public interest in American space exploration, bringing the number of telegrams to the White House to record numbers.

The flight was conducted under the rules of the Interagency Committee for Outer Space Activities (IOCCSA) and was a cooperative flight under the control of the US, with no crew, but under Soviet supervision.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (volcanic glass and lava flows), with some sedimentary rock.

St. Helena, historically known as Jamestown Island or James Island, was claimed in 1651 by the British and in 1657 it was chartered by the British crown as a royal colony. It was an important port of call for ships traveling between England and the Caribbean prior to the opening of the Suez Canal. The island's only town, Jamestown, is located on the harbor of the same name; it has a population of about 1,500. Jamestown was originally settled by English colonists in 1619 as the "James Colony", but the island was taken over by the British before the first group of colonists had an opportunity to establish themselves. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of coffee or a stone to the ground, but which is clearly a metaphysical concept, in the case of any event that is not the effect of some preceding cause. The cause of the drop of coffee is the human hand; there is no event which is the effect of the hand dropping the coffee. In the case of other natural events, including human activities such as falling on one's knees or rising to one's feet, no one event clearly and precisely can be identified as the cause of the event of the other. If I say that my right hand threw a ball to my brother's left hand, my right hand is one thing while my brother's left hand is another; it is possible to say what my right hand did, but my brother would say he did not know. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep. A game is 12 regular season halves of 18 minutes in length. (The league used to use 12 15-minute quarters, but dropped them during the 2010 season. They returned in 2011.) Each half is divided into two 6-minute periods. There is a 10-minute halftime.

The field is usually divided into a number of zones, identified by numbers and colored lines (see diagram).

The goal posts are arranged in an "L" formation. They are placed 8 yards (7 m) apart, the goal line being 8-yard wide. The uprights are 7 feet (2.13 m) apart.

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia. It has been undertaken on a massive scale across the planet, resulting in many thousands (if not millions) of hybrids living in zoos and wildlife reserves around the world.

In more recent times, a growing number of hybridisation experiments have been carried out by scientific institutions such as the Bronx Zoo (New York), the San Diego Zoo, and the Los Angeles Zoo.

Hybridisation is not merely a hobby and pastime for zookeepers and zoologists worldwide. It is a serious, responsible and professional undertaking which aims to assist with the conservation of animals which are, or would otherwise be facing oblivion as a result of habitat loss.

It has been shown repeatedly that successful hybridisation can result in offspring which is, indeed, more viable and can out-perform its parents, thus, providing a lifeline

A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is a "system of things unseen and the belief of things incomprehensible by human understanding". Deists believe that there is a God, who created the Universe. Deists also believe that there are natural laws that govern the Universe and God is not involved or involved in a way that humans can understand. Paine criticized the Bible, and other Judeo-Christian books, as "false Deism" and he stated that "All that unites mankind is much more than what divides them", and that the "virtues of public spirit, justice and charity are more prevalent than those of intolerance, selfishness and slander, which are equally repugnant to human nature, though they are so much the objects of the latter". BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school joined The American Athletic Conference (The American) in 2013. Men's basketball will join The American in 2020. A&M–CC was a football independent team for nine years, and in 2014 joined the Southwestern Athletic Conference (SWAC), the current athletic league for the two former A&M–CC members. For most of the school's history, athletic events were mostly held on campus, but since 2017, the football program has held its home games at Kyle Field on the University of Texas at Austin campus with construction of an on-campus stadium completed.

3. Montreal

Lights over the Montreal tower at night and a daytime view from the Jacques Cartier bridge | Getty Images

The Montreal metro area stretches along the shore of a wide bay but is separated from the Atlantic Oceans by the St. Lawrence River. But winter visitors shouldn't be too concerned if they're caught by a sudden spell of arctic air; Montreal actually sees its warmest temperatures in July.

The average high in July is 23.3C (73.5F). At least in winter, we might get a preview of the kind of mild temps to come in the summer months.

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s, as did Joe McCarthy's rise to power during those same years. While the Catholic Church and Irish-Americans were increasingly looked at with suspicion by many Americans for their supposed influence on national elections in the 1920s, Notre Dame's rising football program, headed by Coach Knute Rockne — and then a young, handsome Joseph P. Kennedy — gave a face and celebrity to the Irish-American experience. Rockne's fame and his willingness to talk about religion in public gave the Irish-Americans a figure they could recognize and relate to.

Joe Kennedy was among the students who crowded into the football stadium to watch Rockne and the Irish win the 1926 season. The Notre Dame victory proved to be one of America's last hurrahs for the New York Giants, as the team had not won a bowl in four years.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Alps, the Jura and the plateau of Ticino. Over 70 cantons belong to the country and every canton is characterized by a specific culture and character. Switzerland is often considered to be a safe nation, given the low crime rate.

The capital city Zurich is most popular for the students studying medicine, arts, economics, finance, computer science and engineering. Also, the University of Applied Sciences and Arts Northwestern Switzerland (FHNW) and the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH Zurich) both offer excellent programs for students looking to study abroad.

Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, it lies within the marine west coast climate zone in which the driest month has less than 67 mm (2.6 in) of precipitation while the wettest month has more than 190 mm (7.5 in) precipitation.

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that Islamic sciences had been handed down from Adam spread in response to the efforts of a group of Islamic thinkers led primarily by Shia Imam Ali al‐Rida. The group called themselves the mujtahids, and, in opposition to the tradition of Sufism, argued for the sole legitimacy of Islamic religious leaders to interpret the divine message. To the mujtahids, the meaning and the truth of divine messages resided not in history—in the interpretation of previous generations of interpreters—but instead in the mind of God as perceived by an individual scholar or "speaker." They argued that God had not, as previously believed, made the religious sciences accessible only to a few learned pious men and women; instead, these sciences were accessible to every Muslim who made himself worthy by following God's message as perceived by a mujtah

Many insects possess very sensitive and, or specialized organs of perception. Some insects such as bees can perceive ultraviolet wavelengths, or detect polarized light, while the eyes of other insects such as ants use the sky for orientation.  Many insects also possess organs of touch to assist in finding their way to specific sites, and these tactile organs can be found in many locations on the body as well as in the antennae.

While humans are capable of hearing sounds in the 20–20,000-hertz frequency range, many insects cannot. They do, however, have excellent hearing qualities at low frequencies, while most humans lack hearing at the high frequencies. Hearing sensitivity can also be used in communication between insects, such as when a katydid has courtship sounds with certain frequency content that attract the female of the next generation.

Israel's Supreme Court is at the head of the court system in the State of Israel. It is the highest judicial instance. The Supreme Court sits in both its own seat and the National Court seat. As of 2019, it has a permanent panel of thirteen justices. It does not require a two-thirds majority to form a decision; decisions are only published after an internal discussion, but can be given by a simple majority which is defined by four of its members. The decisions of the Supreme Court are legally binding, even if they are not carried out.
